title: 103_hr2328
content:
The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the Act. The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" aims to conserve natural and cultural resources by engaging young men and women in a Public Lands Corps. This provides education and work opportunities while benefiting the economy and environment. Many public lands and Indian reservations require labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to perform cost-effective conservation, rehabilitation, and improvement work on public and Indian lands where existing employees cannot do so. Youth conservation corps have a good track record of efficiently restoring and maintaining facilities in partnership with government agencies. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to involve young men and women in public service to enhance their understanding of natural and cultural resources, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation careers. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to involve young men and women in public service to enhance their understanding of natural and cultural resources, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation careers. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 defines key terms such as "Corps," "public lands," and "qualified youth or conservation corps" to establish programs for individuals between 16 and 25 years old to work in natural or cultural resource settings. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any recognized group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. "Indian" is defined as a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" encompass real property owned or held by Indian tribes with restrictions on alienation. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to efforts focused on preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. SEC. 4. PUBLIC LANDS CORPS PROGRAM. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrolled individuals must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. Enrollees are exempt from civil service laws. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects with long-term public benefits and that promote a work ethic and public service. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects on public or Indian lands. Projects should promote a sense of public service, be labor-intensive, prompt, and offer educational opportunities. All projects must be consistent with relevant laws and policies. The Secretaries are authorized to provide necessary services and facilities for these programs. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects on public or Indian lands. They may establish and use conservation centers for these programs, with logistical support from the Secretary of Defense when feasible. Basic standards of health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety must be enforced at the conservation centers. Contracts with State and local government agencies and private organizations may be made for management purposes. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program authorizes the placement of qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies to conduct research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide, with a focus on diversity. The program aims to provide opportunities for underrepresented groups in natural resource management. The Resource Assistant Program aims to augment the Federal land managing agencies' workforce by utilizing college students and recent graduates, providing exposure to potential career opportunities. Existing nonprofit organizations may also implement the program, with private funding required to cover 25% of participant costs. The Resource Assistant program requires nonprofit organizations to cover 25% of participant costs and submit an annual report evaluating the program's impact on the agency's mission. SEC. 6. LIVING ALLOWANCES AND TERMS OF SERVICE FOR PARTICIPANTS. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants will receive a living allowance not exceeding the maximum established for national service program participants. They must agree to a specified term of service set by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, consistent with national service program requirements. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants will receive educational benefits or awards. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. They may also receive forbearance on Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Borrowers in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program can request forbearance from lenders while serving, in line with regulations, to receive post-service educational benefits. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 apply to activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Cost Sharing:
- The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps.
- The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources.
- No cost sharing required for projects on Indian lands.
- Foundations associated with Federal land managing agencies can contribute to Public Lands Corps project costs. The Act allows the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to receive funds for programs without restrictions under the National and Community Service Act. Appropriations are authorized as needed to implement the Act.
